instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS? This is PPBUS_G3H after passing through a current sense resistor that splits it off from the rest of PPBUS_G3H. The purpose of this is so that we can measure how much current is flowing to this part of the machine..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
This one came as no power, very small signs of corrosion, cleaned up, nothing creating short or discontinuity. No green/orange light, no fan spin, no warmth on CPU.

It draws 25mA from the charger hence I checked <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>, 3.1 mV

Performed the checks on repair.wiki:
[LIST]
[*]<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> is corroded and you can't see it: it looks good I haven't removed it, no corrosion in the area.
[*]Corrosion on probe points for SPI ROM <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> area: very clean
[*]Bad clock chip <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>: nothing visible
[*]Corrosion on RTC pullup resistors <RESISTOR>R1300</RESISTOR> to <RESISTOR>R1303</RESISTOR> (or <CAPACITOR>C1300</CAPACITOR>/<CAPACITOR>C1303</CAPACITOR> shorted to ground): Both resistors measure 20K as expected, caps are not shorted
[*]If you remove <RESISTOR>R8111</RESISTOR> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> comes back: removed this resistor, no change on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>, put it back.
[/LIST]
<CAPACITOR>C7583</CAPACITOR> was most impacted by corrosion, removed it and not yet replaced as it looked like the smallest of the 4 parallel resistors to ground on that line.

Further measurements:

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.42V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8.63V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is high
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.433V
<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 3.329V
<SIGNAL>PHC_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL> = 3.324V
<SIGNAL>PHC_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> = 3.336V

then <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0.620V !

Traced <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> back to <TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR> (hope this is correct), VIN is fine at 8.6V but VSW (pins 6/7/8) are 0.620V again.

Should I suspect a faulty <TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR> or anything else I can check before changing it ? Just wanted to check I am not travelling too far in the wrong direction.

EDIT: Moving onto <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL> = 1.01V, instead of 8.6V, checking this rail now

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL> = 1.01V"
Check <RESISTOR>R5430</RESISTOR> and its traces.

<CAPACITOR>C7583</CAPACITOR> is not critical, forget it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R5430</RESISTOR> is not installed, but the upper pins are reading 8.6v, moreover, <CAPACITOR>C7540</CAPACITOR>/41/42 <CAPACITOR>C7570</CAPACITOR> all reading 8.6v. <TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR> pin 1 is also 8.6v.
Then <CAPACITOR>C7500</CAPACITOR>, pin 1 reads 1V.

Corroded pads of <CAPACITOR>C7583</CAPACITOR> (that was removed earlier) are pretty much right on the other side of <CAPACITOR>C7500</CAPACITOR>. It is a bit like 8.6v on the front of the board and 1V on the back. Could it be that one of the pads is actually a via and now acting as a resistor? I may just be making up things.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
You must have the same voltage on that power rail, doesn't matter which side of the board is.
One passing hole is corroded...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I think that's the case, between <CAPACITOR>C7541</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7500</CAPACITOR> pin 1s it is 0.5Mohm if I didn't measure it incorrectly. Will check again tomorrow. Thanks for the help.
